head.title: Regenerative Electrocatalytic Redox Cycle of Copper Sulfide for Sustainable NH3 Production under Ambient Conditions | ACS Catalysis

meta.content: Regenerative Electrocatalytic Redox Cycle of Copper Sulfide for Sustainable NH3 Production under Ambient Conditions

Electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) is a promising method for energy-efficient and low-emission NH3 production. Herein, we report electrochemical NH3 production using a copper sulfide-based electrocatalyst. A solid-state synthesis is employed to prepare the Cu9S5 catalyst for artificial N2 fixation in a neutral aqueous electrolyte. Despite an excellent NRR activity of 10.8 ± 0.4 μg/hcm2 at −0.5 VRHE, however, the catalyst itself is reductively degraded during the NRR. To achieve continuous electrochemical NH3 production, a regenerative electrochemical sulfur cycle is introduced that revives the Cu9S5 crystal structure and NRR activities. The electrochemical regeneration process reconstructing the metal–sulfur bond in between sequential NH3 production processes restores the NRR activity. Importantly, catalytic surfaces providing a labile sulfhydryl functional group attached to the N2-adsorption metal center are required to achieve efficient NRR activity under ambient conditions.

SUBJECTS:

div.p:
Electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) is a promising method for energy-efficient and low-emission NH
3
production. Herein, we report electrochemical NH
3
production using a copper sulfide-based electrocatalyst. A solid-state synthesis is employed to prepare the Cu
9
S
5
catalyst for artificial N
2
fixation in a neutral aqueous electrolyte. Despite an excellent NRR activity of 10.8 ± 0.4 μg/hcm
2
at −0.5 V
RHE
, however, the catalyst itself is reductively degraded during the NRR. To achieve continuous electrochemical NH
3
production, a regenerative electrochemical sulfur cycle is introduced that revives the Cu
9
S
5
crystal structure and NRR activities. The electrochemical regeneration process reconstructing the metal–sulfur bond in between sequential NH
3
production processes restores the NRR activity. Importantly, catalytic surfaces providing a labile sulfhydryl functional group attached to the N
2
-adsorption metal center are required to achieve efficient NRR activity under ambient conditions.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Ammonia (NH
3
) is a key chemical component in various industrial fields because of its widespread use in fertilizers, plastic, textiles, and many other products.
(1−3)
Moreover, it is attractive as an easily transportable hydrogen carrier with a high liquefaction temperature and low pressure.
(2,4)
In 2017, over 150 million tons of NH
3
were produced globally, and the need for NH
3
continues to grow.
(5)
Since the commercialization of the NH
3
production process by BASF in 1905, almost all synthetic NH
3
is generated by the Haber–Bosch process, which is a thermochemical reaction at high temperatures (300–500 °C) and pressures (150–300 atm) using high-purity hydrogen and nitrogen as reactants.
(2,6)
Due to the high temperatures and pressures required, the Haber–Bosch process is heavily dependent upon fossil fuels and emits a large amount of CO
2
to produce stream-reformed hydrogen.
(2,7)
The harsh reaction conditions are required to break the strong triple bond of N
2
and achieve economically feasible production yields and conversion rates.

Recently, electrochemical nitrogen reduction reactions (eNRRs) have been suggested as an alternative method to produce NH
3
from N
2
and H
2
O under ambient conditions.
(8,9)
The eNRR process utilizes electromotive force to break the triple covalent bond of N
2
, D
0
(bond-dissociation energy) = 941 kJ/mol, which requires the adsorption of N
2
to an active electrocatalyst, facilitating the hydrogenation process. With appropriate catalysis, eNRRs can produce NH
3
with no carbon footprint, using only renewable electricity and saving energy costs. However, no practical catalyst has been reported as yet for efficient eNRRs with high activity, selectivity, and durability.
(10−12)

To improve eNRR performance, various eNRR catalysts have been investigated, including noble metal,
(12)
transition-metal oxide,
(13)
nitride,
(14)
carbide,
(15)
sulfide,
(5)
and metal-free catalysts.
(16)
Among the different catalysts investigated, metal dichalcogenide groups have garnered significant interest owing to their resemblance to the natural N
2
fixation cofactor of nitrogenase.
(17)
N
2
adsorption to the metal active center and atomic hydrogen relay by the neighboring sulfur to the adsorbed N
2
are the critical reaction steps to elongate the covalent bonding of N
2
for enzymatic NH
3
production. Similar eNRR mechanisms were proposed for
[email protected]
2
/CFC,
(18)
Fe
2
(MoO
4
),
(19)
and Fe
3
Mo
3
C/C,
(20)
reporting high activity and selectivity (8.45 μg/hcm
2
, 18.16 μg/hmg
cat
, 13.55 μg/hcm
2
and 2.96%, 9.1%, 14.74% for the reaction rate and FE, respectively).

Metal sulfides have also been studied rigorously over the past several decades for their applications in many different fields, including photocatalysis,
(21)
biomedicine,
(22)
sensors,
(23)
energy storage,
(24)
and others. Importantly, material decomposition of metal sulfides during specific electrochemical reactions has been widely studied. Bard et al. reported the decomposition of CdS to CdS/Cd
0
and CdS/S
0
in photoelectrochemical reactions.
(25)
The electrochemical reduction of CdS coupled to chemical dissolution proceeds rapidly in the presence of excited electrons, and PbS showed similar degradations.
(25)
In particular, when using the FeS
x
catalyst in oxygen evolution reaction (OER), it is known that the catalyst oxidizes to form FeO
x
.
(26)
Previous reports imply a similar durability problem expected in eNRRs using sulfide catalysts due to the instability of chalcogenide catalysis. Ye et al. reported that the crystal phase of metal sulfide-based materials changes due to the following reaction in eNRR reactions in a 0.1 M phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) aqueous electrolyte (MS
2
+ 2H
2
O + 4e
–
→ M + 2HS
–
+ 2OH
–
).
(27)
Moreover, according to a recent report by Kim et al., the composition of the Cu
1.81
S catalyst also changes to Cu
2
O when NRR is performed in an alkaline electrolyte.
(28)
However, no study has reported on the regeneration of metal sulfides for sustainable eNRRs.

In this work, we designed and prepared a Cu
9
S
5
/NC (NC: N-doped carbon) composite reaction with a thermal heating process in an Ar atmosphere for use as an eNRR electrocatalyst. The digenite surface exhibited a decisive activity toward NRR at −0.5 V
RHE
in 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
. Despite the effective synthetic process and remarkable NRR activity (35 ± 3% of FE and NH
3
production yield of 630 ± 20 nmol/hcm
2
and 10.8 ± 0.4 μg/hcm
2
at −0.5 V
RHE
), however, the catalyst composition changed to Cu
2
O during the NRR due to the weak metal–sulfide bond of the Cu
9
S
5
/NC. To overcome this drawback of metal sulfide catalysts, the degraded surface of Cu
9
S
5
/NC, i.e., Cu
2
O, was reconstructed using an electrochemical regeneration process in between consecutive eNRR reactions. This electrochemical regeneration method was inspired by the conformational changes including the sulfhydryl group (HS
–
) of the nitrogenase cofactor.
(29)
The regenerative electrochemical metal oxide/sulfide redox cycle produces NH
3
and H
2
in the repeated N
2
fixation reactions using dissolved N
2
and H
2
O as the reactants.

To the best of our knowledge, no studies have reported on the stepwise electrochemical NH
3
production using an oxide/sulfur redox cycle mimicking the natural catalytic cycle of N
2
fixation. This unprecedented means to achieve continuous eNRR reactions provides an insight into the electrochemical N
2
reduction mechanism on metal sulfide surfaces. The surface states of Cu
9
S
5
in the redox cycle were carefully assessed by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), while the production of NH
3
was confirmed by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and colorimetric methods (UV–vis). Thus, we expect that the regeneration redox cycle of eNRR catalysis presented here will provide novel methods of material development for efficient eNRR catalysis.

div.div:
CuCl
2
·2H
2
O (Sigma-Aldrich), Cu(NO
3
)
2
·2.5H
2
O (Sigma-Aldrich), ethylene glycol (99.8%, Sigma-Aldrich), Na
2
S (99%, Sigma-Aldrich),
15
NH
4
Cl, (98 atom %, Sigma-Aldrich), para(dimethylamino) benzaldehyde (99%, Sigma-Aldrich), thiourea (99%, Junsei), ethanol (95%, Daejung Co. Ltd.), and isopropyl alcohol (IPA, 99.5%, Duksan) were of analytical grade and used as received without further purification.

A mixture of Cu(NO
3
)
2
·2.5H
2
O (0.8 g) and thiourea (1.2 g) was well mixed, transferred into a ceramic crucible, and then heated in a tube furnace at 773 K for 1 h at a heating rate of 8.3 K/min under an Ar gas flow. After the thermal reaction, the catalyst was washed with deionized (DI) water four times.

CuCl
2
·2H
2
O (1 g) and thiourea (1 g) were put into ethylene glycol (40 mL). After stirring for 30 min, the precursors were heated in an oven controlled at 423 K for 4 h under autoclave conditions. After that, the as-made catalyst was washed with triple-distilled water and ethanol several times.

Cu(NO
3
)
2
·2.5H
2
O (0.896 g), poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP, MW = 55 000, Sigma), and thiourea (0.2944 g) were put into ethylene glycol (200 mL). After stirring for 30 min, the precursors were heated in an oven controlled at 433 K for 24 h under pressure bottle conditions. After that, the as-made catalyst was washed with triple-distilled water and ethanol several times.

0.5 g (2.15 mmol) of Cu(NO
3
)
2
·2.5H
2
O was dissolved in 15 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF, Sigma-Aldrich, 99.9%) and then, 0.301 g (1.43 mmol) of trimesic acid (H
3
BTC, Sigma-Aldrich, 99.9%) was added. After stirring for 30 min, the solution was kept in a glass vial at 80 °C for 8 h and then cooled to room temperature. Blue crystals (Cu-HKUST-1) were obtained. After washing with DMF and solvent-exchange with acetonitrile (MeCN, Sigma-Aldrich, 99.9%) for 1 d, the product was heated to 80 °C under a static vacuum for 12 h. The as-synthesized Cu-HKUST-1 was added to a crucible, which was then placed in a tube furnace and heated to 800 °C under Ar (99.999%) at a heating rate of 4.3 °C/min. After reaching the target temperature, the material was maintained for 3 h and then naturally allowed to cool to room temperature. After the heating process, the obtained powder (0.1 g) and thiourea (0.3 g) were well mixed, transferred into a ceramic crucible, and then heated in a tube furnace at 873 K for 3 h at a heating rate of 3.3 K/min under an Ar gas flow. After the thermal reaction, the catalyst was washed with deionized (DI) water several times.

Wet dispersed Cu
9
S
5
/NC or Cu
9
S
5
catalysts were hand-sprayed onto carbon paper (2.5 cm × 2.5 cm, Toray T-120) and dried in a desiccator at ambient temperature to prepare working electrodes. All catalysts were loaded at 1 mg/cm
2
. The catalyst ink was prepared by mixing 10 mg of catalyst powder and 1 mL of the IPA solution. The working electrode was rinsed with 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
to remove soluble contaminants adsorbed on the surface before starting the experiment. The electrolyte used for eNRR was 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
(99%, aqueous solution). The NH
3
absorber trap attached to the electrolysis chamber contained 40 mL of a 10 mM H
2
SO
4
aqueous solution. Anion-exchange membranes (FAA-3, Fumatech), used to separate the cathodic and anodic chambers of the H cell, were pretreated in 1 M KOH for 24 h and DI water for another 1 h before NRR tests. A Bio-Logic SP-300 potentiostat was used for all electrochemical experiments. The electrochemical experiments were performed at room temperature and pressure. For a three-electrode configuration, the standard calomel electrode (SCE) and graphite rod were used as the reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively, and the carbon paper electrode covered by catalyst powder was used as the working electrode. In this study, all potentials were converted into the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The NRR activity was investigated using chronoamperometry (CA) measured from −0.4 to −0.8 V
RHE
for 1 h each at the different potentials. For NRR,
14
N
2
(99.999%, Sinyang) or
15
N
2
(98 atom %, Sigma) was bubbled for approximately 20 min before the measurements and continuously purged into the cathodic compartment during the experiments at flow rates of 250 ccm and 5 ccm/min, respectively, for
14
N
2
and
15
N
2
. Redox characteristics of the catalyst in different electrolyte solutions were studied in cyclic voltammograms (CV) performed on the catalyst loaded on a glassy carbon (GC) electrode at a scan rate of 50 mV/s. The potential of the reference electrode was calibrated using 5 mM K
3
[FeCN]
6
as the standard redox reaction at the Pt/C electrode (
E
0
= 0.361 V
NHE
at 25 °C).

div.h3: Regeneration of the Metal Chalcogenide Electrode
div.div:
In between NRR measurements, the electrode regeneration procedure was performed at a constant potential of +0.1 V
RHE
for 1 h in a deaerated aqueous solution of 50 mM Na
2
S and 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
. After the regeneration, the electrode was thoroughly washed with DI water before the consecutive NRR as stated above. The NRR and electrochemical sulfurization process were repeated several times, and the NH
3
produced in longer time measurements was quantified.

X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra were obtained using a Rigaku (MiniFlex-2) equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained using an Inspect F50 microscope with an accelerating voltage of 10 kV. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were recorded on a transmission electron microscope (Talos F200X). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were obtained using a PHI Versa Probe system with a 100-W Al Kα X-ray source.

Low-temperature nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at 77 K on an adsorption volumetric analyzer BEL Mini manufactured by BEL, Inc. (Japan). All samples were degassed at 393 K for 12 h under a static vacuum before adsorption measurements. The specific surface area (SSA) was determined by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method for nitrogen adsorption isotherms in the range of 0.05–0.20 relative pressure (
P
/
P
0
). Pore size distribution (PSD) was determined by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The total pore volume was obtained at 0.99
P
/
P
0
. Thermal-programmed desorption (TPD) was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 TPR/TPD. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements were recorded using an SDT Q600 device (TA Instruments Inc., New Castle, DE).

The final NH
3
concentration was determined by indophenol blue methods. First, a 1 mL aliquot of the solution was taken by the electrochemical cathodic reactor or absorber. Then, 1 mL of a phenol solution (0.64 M C
6
H
5
OH, 0.38 M NaOH, and 1.3 mM C
5
FeN
6
Na
2
O) and 1 mL of hypochlorite solution (55 mM NaOCl and 0.75 M NaOH) were added. After 2 h at room temperature, the sample absorbance was analyzed by UV–vis spectroscopy from 900 to 350 nm. The UV–vis spectra were obtained using a Cary UV–visible 100 spectrophotometer (Agilent). The absorbance peaks were shown at 633 nm, calibrated by subtracting the background absorbance measured at 875 nm. In the UV–vis spectrum, the background absorbance represents 0 ppm (NH
3
) of the bulk electrolyte solution. In addition,
1
H NMR (nuclear magnetic resonance) spectra of
14
N and
15
N were obtained using a Bruker Avance III HD 400 MHz to confirm NH
3
production. For
1
H NMR detection of NH
3
, 0.1 mL of 1 M H
2
SO
4
was added to 1 mL of electrolyte solutions and carefully sealed to minimize the effects of ambient NH
3
in the atmosphere (pH 2). For measurements, 0.055 mL of D
2
O (99%, Sigma) was added to 0.495 mL of the sample solution. For isotope quantification using
1
H NMR, a controlled amount of
15
NH
4
Cl (98 atom %, Sigma, 0.5–10 ppm) added to a 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
electrolyte solution was used to construct a standard calibration curve (64 scans at each
1
H NMR measurement).

The amount of possible byproduct of electrochemical NH
3
production, i.e., N
2
H
4
, was determined using the Watt and Chrisp method. A mixture of para(dimethylamino) benzaldehyde (6 g), HCl (37%, 30 mL), and ethanol (300 mL) was used as an indicator. The measurement was performed after 2 mL of electrolyte and 2 mL of indicator solution were mixed for 5 min. To quantify the amount of N
2
H
4
, a standard calibration curve was drawn from a serial dilution of a N
2
H
4
·H
2
O solution in 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
. The absorbance of N
2
H
4
was measured at 455 nm in a UV–vis spectrometer.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst was synthesized by grinding Cu(NO
3
)
2
·2.5H
2
O and CH
4
N
2
S powder in a mortar, followed by heat treatment (
Figure
1
a). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-prepared catalyst are presented in
Figure
1
b. The XRD peaks of Cu
9
S
5
/NC are observed at 2θ = 26.24 27.8, 29.2, 32.2, 37.1, 41.4, 46.2, 49.4, and 54.7°, which indexed to (101), (0015), (107), (1010), (0114), (0117), (0120), (119), and (1115) planes of hexagonal Cu
9
S
5
(JCPDS no. 47-1847,
Figure
1
b), respectively.
(30)
The morphology of the catalyst was investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (
Figure
1
c,d). As shown in
Figure
1
c, the catalyst is comprised of irregularly shaped chunks. Cu
9
S
5
/NC composites with a size of 1–5 μm are seen in the SEM images. The composite structure of Cu
9
S
5
/NC is clearly visible in the TEM image (
Figure
1
d). The high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) lattice image of Cu
9
S
5
/NC shows the 0.321 nm lattice fringe corresponding to the (0015) plane of Cu
9
S
5
and carbonaceous material attached to the Cu
9
S
5
(
Figure
1
d).
(31−33)
Cu
9
S
5
without NC samples presents a flowerlike morphology along with sheetlike plates and sizes ranging from 5 to 10 μm (
Figure S1a
). However, the crystal structure was not affected by the existence of NC, as shown in the XRD patterns (JCPDS no. 47-1847,
Figure S1b
).
(31,33)
In the Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst, the mass ratio of the remaining catalyst was 74%, as estimated using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (
Figure S2a
).

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) Scheme of the synthetic procedure for Cu
9
S
5
/NC. (b) XRD pattern of the Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst. (c) SEM image of Cu
9
S
5
/NC and (d) TEM image of Cu
9
S
5
/NC. (e) Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) elemental mapping of Cu
9
S
5
/NC. The inset image in (c) (left) shows HR-TEM (right) of Cu
9
S
5
/NC.

div.div:
Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analysis shows a homogeneous distribution of Cu, S, C, and N over the entire structure of the Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst (
Figure
1
e). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) survey spectrum also shows that the composite contains Cu, S, C, and N, in agreement with the EDX mapping results (
Figure
2
a). The Cu 2p spectrum displays two main peaks located at 933.9 and 953.8 eV, corresponding to Cu
1+
of Cu in Cu
9
S
5
/NC.
(32,33)
A pair of weak peaks at 943.7 and 958.4 eV is attributed to Cu
2+
of Cu in Cu
9
S
5
/NC. The other peak (934.9 and 954.7 eV) is the satellite peak of Cu (
Figure
2
b).
(32,33)
As shown in
Figure
2
c, the peaks at 162.3, 163.5, 164.6, 165.7, and 170.3 eV in the high-resolution S 2p spectrum show the existence of Cu–S (162.3, 163.5 eV), S–S (164.6, 165.7 eV), and Cu–S–C (170.3 eV) covalent bonds.
(34,35,43)
The high-resolution N 1s spectrum is shown in
Figure
2
d. Four fitted peaks located at 400.1, 401.1, 402, and 406.7 eV are assigned to pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, quaternary N, and N oxide, respectively.
(36,37)

div.p:
Figure 2. Survey scan of Cu
9
S
5
/NC (a) high-resolution XPS, (b) Cu 2p, (c) S 2p, and (d) N 1s of Cu
9
S
5
/NC.

div.div:
The conductive support, i.e., N-doped carbon (NC), was employed in Cu
9
S
5
/NC to improve the active surface area in the catalysis. The textural properties of Cu
9
S
5
/NC and Cu
9
S
5
were measured by N
2
adsorption analysis to estimate the catalytic surface area. The estimated specific surface area (SSA) and total pore volume are 12.3 m
2
/g and 0.084 cm
3
/g for Cu
9
S
5
/NC and 8.1 m
2
/g and 0.051 cm
3
/g for Cu
9
S
5
, respectively, from N
2
adsorption/desorption isotherms (
Figure S2b,c
). According to the BJH plot, as expected, Cu
9
S
5
/NC has higher mesoporosity from 2 to 8 nm than Cu
9
S
5
. Thus, it is expected that the high surface area and porous structure of Cu
9
S
5
/NC result in more exposed active sites for NRR electrocatalysis than unsupported Cu
9
S
5
(see below).

The nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) performance of Cu
9
S
5
/NC was investigated in a N
2
-saturated 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
electrolyte using an H cell under ambient conditions (
Figure
3
a). In the cyclic voltammetry (CV), the current density in the N
2
-saturated electrolyte solution did not show a clear difference compared to that observed in the Ar-saturated solution. It is difficult to find a distinctive peak current or onset potential for NRR, but the onset potential for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is clearly detected at approximately −0.7 V
RHE
(reversible hydrogen electrode) under both N
2
and Ar atmospheres. Instead, the NRR activity of Cu
9
S
5
/NC could only be estimated by the amount of NH
3
detected in the electrolyte solution after 1 h of chronoamperometry (CA) at different potentials (see below;
Figure
3
b). However, the current observed in the CV and CA changed over time, as also shown in the changed double-layer charging current in consecutive CV cycles (
Figure
3
a). This occurs mainly due to the composition change of Cu
9
S
5
under the electrochemical reaction conditions (see below). As reported by Kong et al., it is difficult to estimate the NRR activity from CV, given that the catalyst is unstable and NRR activity is significant compared to the hydrogen evolution reaction or degradation current.
(13)
Therefore, CA was used at longer time points to investigate the NRR activity and FE of Cu
9
S
5
/NC at different potentials.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) CV curves of Cu
9
S
5
/NC in Ar- and N
2
-saturated conditions. (b) NH
3
yield and FE (%) at different potentials (−0.4 to −0.8 V
RHE
) on the Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst. (c) Chronoamperometric curves of Cu
9
S
5
/NC at −0.5 V for 16 h. (d) XRD spectra of the Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst after 1 h of CA at −0.5 V in a N
2
-saturated electrolyte solution. (e) Chronoamperometric curves of Cu
9
S
5
/NC at −0.5 V in an Ar- or N
2
-saturated atmosphere. (f) XRD spectra of the Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst after HER at −0.5 V in an Ar-saturated electrolyte solution.

div.div:
CA was performed to determine the NRR activity of Cu
9
S
5
/NC and Cu
9
S
5
catalysts at different potentials ranging from −0.4 to −0.8 V
RHE
in a N
2
-saturated 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
electrolyte (
Figures
3
b and
S3
). The UV–vis spectrum of the indophenol blue solution prepared from the electrolyte solution after the CA experiment is shown in
Figure S4
. The NH
3
yield was then calculated from the absorption at 633 nm in comparison to the standard calibration curve after subtracting the background absorption from a blank solution (
Figure S4
). For the Cu
9
S
5
/NC surface, the NH
3
production yield reached a peak of 10.8 ± 0.4 μg/hcm
2
(or 630 ± 20 nmol/hcm
2
) at −0.5 V
RHE
(
Figure
3
b). The NRR performance of Cu
9
S
5
/NC is comparable to that of the best NRR catalysts previously reported in the literature (
Table S1
). To confirm the electrochemical NRR results obtained on the Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst, additional control CA experiments were performed. These control experimental conditions include (1) using a carbon paper electrode without Cu
9
S
5
/NC under a N
2
atmosphere, (2) using a Cu
9
S
5
/NC electrode and open-circuit potential without applied potentials under a N
2
atmosphere, and (3) using Cu
9
S
5
/NC and −0.5 V
RHE
in an Ar-saturated 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
electrolyte solution (
Figure S5
). Under all of these conditions, negligible amounts of NH
3
were produced. These experiments confirm that NH
3
was synthesized by the electrochemical NRR reaction at the controlled potential in the presence of supplied N
2
gas.
1
H (
14
N and
15
N) nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) analysis was performed to further support the colorimetric observation of NH
3
production (
Figure S6
). In the
1
H NMR measurements, triplet and doublet peaks of
14
NH
3
and
15
NH
3
NMR were observed, which strongly supports the production of NH
3
in the electrolyte solution by the electrochemical NRR. Watt and Chrisp’s method was used to detect N
2
H
4
produced by a possible side reaction of the NRR, but no detectable N
2
H
4
was produced (
Figure S7
). Thus, we conclude that the Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst produces NH
3
by electrochemical N
2
fixation under ambient conditions. In addition, a quantitative analysis of
15
NH
3
was performed using a
1
H NMR measurement. As a result, the NH
3
production yield of 0.7 ppm (439 nmol/hcm
2
and 7.5 μg/hcm
2
) at −0.5 V
RHE
and FE of 25.2%, respectively, were estimated from the NRR under a
15
N
2
atmosphere (
Figures S6 and S8
). The concentration is approximately 70% of that calculated from the indophenol blue methods. Note that the
14
NH
3
peaks are also shown in
Figure S6
, so a possible
14
N
2
leak through the reactor vessel was speculated to be the reason for the difference between
1
H NMR and UV–vis quantifications of NH
3
. However, the results obtained in the isotope experiments confirmed the electrochemical NRR undergone by the supplied
15
N
2
gases.

To investigate the effect of NC on the NRR activity of Cu
9
S
5
/NC, NRR activity was also evaluated using the Cu
9
S
5
catalyst in a 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
electrolyte (
Figure S10
). The Cu
9
S
5
catalyst exhibited an FE of 7.0% and a reaction rate of 7.9 μg/hcm
2
(420 nmol/hcm
2
) at −0.5 V
RHE
, which is 35% less activity and 80% less selectivity (FE) compared to Cu
9
S
5
/NC. The difference in NRR activity and selectivity is partially due to the differences in SSA (
Figure S2
) and the composition. The conductive surface area measurements of Cu
9
S
5
and Cu
9
S
5
/NC also clearly indicate that Cu
9
S
5
/NC has a higher active surface than Cu
9
S
5
, as demonstrated by a 24% steeper slope in the charging current density plot vs scan rates (
Figure S11a–c
). N
2
-TPD analysis also shows that Cu
9
S
5
/NC has 28% more N
2
adsorption sites than Cu
9
S
5
, which is beneficial for the NRR (
Figure S11d
). The N
2
chemisorption properties of Cu
9
S
5
and Cu
9
S
5
/NC appear in distinct peaks at about 180 and 240 °C. Cu
9
S
5
/NC showed a slightly higher adsorption capacity due to the porous structure of NC (
Figure S2
). The NC also provides a facile electron transfer between the semiconducting Cu
9
S
5
and supporting electrode (carbon paper), so it might decrease unnecessary ohmic drop through the electrode.
(6,40,47)
Due to the advantages of the Cu
9
S
5
/NC composite structure, it is used to further study the degradation and regeneration of Cu
9
S
5
catalysts in NRR as discussed below. Also, owing to the unsaturated coordination of Cu–S catalysts, the N
2
gas molecule would be weakly chemisorbed on the Cu
9
S
5
/NC surface to form a Cu
9
S
5
–N
2
bond. According to the density-functional theory (DFT) simulations, the NRR mechanism in the Cu
9
S
5
/NC case is expected to have distal and mixed pathways.
(12,27,38,39)
To observe the NRR activity with different ratios of Cu and S, CuS and Cu
1.96
S catalysts were further prepared using a hydrothermal method (
Figures S11 and S12
).
(41,42)
On comparing the NRR activity at −0.5 V
RHE
, both catalysts presented lower activity compared to that of Cu
9
S
5
(see
Table S2
). The effect of the Cu–S structure on the NRR was recently studied in these catalysts, and it is suggested that threefold-coordinate Cu sites of Cu–S catalysts enable N–H···S hydrogen bonding during N
2
H
y
adsorption, which results in efficient NRR activities (
Figure S13 and Table S2
).
(28)

The electrochemical reaction rate (i.e., current) is usually enhanced with increased overpotentials. The exponential increase of current over the applied overpotential is explained by the Butler–Volmer equation using two simple variables—transfer coefficient and overpotential. Interestingly, NRR activity and FE of Cu
9
S
5
/NC were significantly reduced at more negative potentials as shown in
Table
1
and
Figures
3
b and
S3b
. The NH
3
production rate was decreased from 630 ± 20 to 22 nmol/hcm
2
, or 10.8 ± 0.4 μg/hcm
2
, as the applied potential increased from −0.5 to −0.7 V
RHE
. The inverse relationship between the NRR activity and overpotentials is likely attributable to two possible effects: (i) the N
2
adsorption is hindered at more negative surfaces, and proton adsorption and reduction dominate the reduction reactions,
(43)
or (ii) the surface actually changes at the negative potentials or is electrochemically degraded and thus loses its catalytic activity. A reduced reaction rate with increased overpotentials is also suggested by the inverted Marcus region for electrochemical reactions, but this is not considered in this study.
(44)

Table 1.
J
NH
3
Value, FE, and NH
3
Yield (Electrode Area, Per Weight) of Cu
9
S
5
/NC Catalysts at Different Potentials

The decreased NRR activity at larger overpotentials for Cu
9
S
5
/NC was observed with decreased current density, corresponding to both HER and NRR, in an extended CA experiment under a N
2
atmosphere (
Figure
3
c). The total current density of Cu
9
S
5
/NC was decreased from −0.4 to −0.1 mA/cm
2
at −0.5 V
RHE
in 16 h of CA. Additionally, the surface degradation of the Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst was examined by XRD after NRR activity measurements after 16 h of the CA reaction at −0.5 V
RHE
(
Figure
3
d). The intensity of XRD peaks corresponding to hexagonal Cu
9
S
5
dramatically decreased after the reduction reactions, while the patterns of cubic Cu
2
O appeared (
Figure
3
d). More interestingly, the changes in the CA and catalyst structure were only observed in the N
2
-saturated aqueous solution, but the reduction current and crystal structure were intact after 1 h of HER at −0.5 V
RHE
in the Ar-saturated electrolyte solution; moreover, the XRD analysis shows that the structure of Cu
9
S
5
is maintained after HER at −0.5 V
RHE
in the Ar-saturated aqueous solution (
Figure
3
e,f). This implies that the catalyst surface is restructured specifically after NRR, and not after HER. In other words, the strong adsorption of N
2
onto the Cu–S surface breaks the labile Cu–S bonds to form the Cu
2
O structure in NRR, but the proton reduction does not modify the surface structure. XPS analysis of the Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst after NRR (
Figure S15
) shows that the Cu 2p XPS spectra are not significantly different from the as-made Cu
9
S
5
/NC, as the Cu
2
O and Cu
9
S
5
oxidation states and electron binding energy are similar. In addition, the N 1s spectra also did not change significantly after NRR, confirming that nitrogen in NC inside the catalyst does not generate NH
3
by NRR (
Figure S15 and Table S3
). However, the peaks of sulfur anions (S
2–
or S
2
2–
at 161.5 eV) dissolved during the NRR process appear in S 2p spectra, along with SO
4
2–
at 170 eV from the Na
2
SO
4
electrolyte (
Figure S15
).
(45,46)
After the degradation, Cu–S and S–S bonding peaks from Cu
9
S
5
were still observed; however, the sulfur content decreased rapidly after NRR while the oxygen content increased (
Table S3
). The XRD and XPS results support the electrochemical degradation of Cu
9
S
5
/NC, as does its reduced NRR activity in repeated CAs at −0.5 V
RHE
shown in
Figures
4
a and
S16
. Thiourea, the N-containing reagent used for NC synthesis, does not affect the indophenol detection of NH
3
, and no peak around 633 nm was found in the 10 mM thiourea solution (
Figure S14
). As rigorously discussed in previous studies, the effect of ambient NH
3
or any adsorbed or supplied impurities must be treated carefully for the quantification of NH
3
produced by NRR.
(17,47−50)
The impeded NRR activity at larger overpotential is because the catalyst surface degrades under the electrochemical reaction conditions. The electrochemical formation of Cu
2
O from Cu
9
S
5
in the reductive environment can proceed by the half-reaction shown below.
The electrochemical reduction of metal sulfide was reported by Ye et al., who showed that the SnS
2
catalyst is reductively degraded in a 0.1 M PBS electrolyte.
(27)
Oxidative degradation of Cu
1.81
S is also known to dissolve S in the following reaction during the electrochemical reaction.
(51)
Similarly, reductive degradation of FeS
2
was reported at 0.62 V
NHE
in acid perchlorate solutions (FeS
2
+ 4H
+
+ 2e
–
→ Fe
2+
+ 2H
2
S) by Peters and Majima.
(52)
In addition, the electrochemical destruction and construction of metal–sulfur bonds are demonstrated in devices, such as Li–S batteries.
(53)
Herein, although a faradic peak current related to the reductive degradation of Cu
9
S
5
was not distinctively shown in CV results, the structural change and activity loss at potentials more negative than −0.5 V
RHE
also strongly suggest the electrochemical degradation of the catalyst.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) NH
3
yield and FE of Cu
9
S
5
/NC after five cycles of the repeated NRR test. (b) XRD pattern of as-made Cu
9
S
5
/NC after NRR at −0.5 V
RHE
without Na
2
S treatment and after the electrochemical regeneration process at +0.1 V in 50 mM Na
2
S solution. (c) NH
3
yield of experiments to determine if the regeneration process can occur at other potentials. (d) NH
3
yield and FE after repeated electrochemical regeneration processes. (e) Results of
1
H (
14
N) NMR analysis of NRR using the catalyst regenerated by the first electrochemical regeneration process at 0.1 V
RHE
. (f) CV curve of the Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst with or without 50 mM Na
2
S in a 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
electrolyte.

div.div:
The cleavage of the metal–S bond together with its reconstruction in the FeMo cofactor of nitrogenase is widely accepted as an important chemical process for N
2
adsorption and hydrogen relay by the sulfhydryl group in natural NH
3
production.
(54)
In this study, the Cu–S bond is also dissociated in the NRR process, and it was hypothesized that the reconstruction of the Cu–S bond would revive the NRR activity. Thus, to mimic the labile chemistry of the sulfhydryl group in the FeMo cofactor and to restore the NRR activity, ex situ electrochemical sulfurization reactions were used to rebuild the Cu–S bonds on the Cu
9
S
5
/NC surface. Specifically, the degraded Cu
9
S
5
/NC electrode was re-oxidized in 50 mM Na
2
S and 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
aqueous solution in CA at potentials ranging from −0.9 to 0.1 V
RHE
for 1 h (
Figures
4
b and
S17
). The electrode was then used for NRR in a fresh 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
solution under a N
2
atmosphere (
Figure
4
c). Importantly, the NRR activity was revived on the Cu
9
S
5
/NC electrode treated at potentials more positive than −0.7 V
RHE
in a 50 mM Na
2
S solution. The detailed electrochemical regeneration process is shown in
Figure
5
. The restoration of the Cu
9
S
5
structure was also examined using XRD. The diffraction patterns of hexagonal Cu
9
S
5
reappeared in the regenerated electrodes, while the peaks from Cu
2
O were significantly reduced (
Figure
4
b). In four consecutive NRR/regeneration cycle experiments, the NH
3
production rate was recovered to approximately 68, 52, and 56% compared with the initial NRR performance of the fresh Cu
9
S
5
/NC electrode (
Figures
4
d and
S18, and Table S4
). However, the composite structure of Cu
9
S
5
/NC shown in
Figure
1
c was collapsed, and the Cu
2
O and NC are separated in the repeated NRR and regeneration process as observed under SEM (
Figure S19
). Moreover, after conducting the NRR test at −0.5 to −0.7 V using the different Cu
9
S
5
/NC electrodes, the electrochemical regeneration process under the conditions of 50 mM Na
2
S and 100 mM Na
2
S can confirm that the NRR activity is recovered reproducibly each time (
Figure S20
). These experimental results suggest that continued NRR application of low-durability metal sulfide-based catalysts is possible at specific voltages as long as the electrolyte has a source that can restore sulfur contents in the catalyst (see
Figures S21–S24 and Tables S5 and S6
). Additionally, NRR activity was not completely restored to that of the original composite structure. The NH
3
production of the regenerated electrode was also confirmed by
1
H NMR in addition to the colorimetric method (
Figure
4
e). Both the NMR and indophenol blue analyses indicate that the NRR performance of the catalyst is restored by the electrochemical regeneration process (
Figure S25
).

div.p:
Figure 5. Scheme of the electrochemical NRR and regeneration process at the Cu
9
S
5
/NC electrode.

div.div:
The regeneration of the Cu
9
S
5
structure from Cu
2
O can proceed by the following electrochemical oxidation reaction.
It has been reported that the Cu substrate is oxidized to form Cu
x
S (including Cu
2
S and Cu
9
S
5
) in the presence of sulfide in an aqueous electrolyte solution at potentials more positive than approximately −0.8 V
RHE
.
(55)
In the previous study, a small bumpy current was recorded at around −0.8 V
RHE
in CV for Cu
x
S formation from Cu substrates.
(55,56,5)
Also, no large oxidative current was detected at the potentials around −0.8 V
RHE
from a CV in 50 mM Na
2
S using the degraded Cu
9
S
5
electrode (
Figure
4
f). The peaky oxidation current observed at −0.3 V
RHE
in
Figure
4
f is attributed to the S
n
2–
/S
2–
redox reaction at Cu
9
S
5
surfaces.
(56)
However, no similar oxidation current was observed using a carbon electrode or without the sulfide in the electrolyte solution (
Figures
4
f and
S26
).

The increased NRR activity of the regenerated Cu
9
S
5
/NC electrode and its crystal structure strongly imply that the Cu–S bond is regenerated by the electrochemical treatment. The results also indicate that the metal–sulfur bond is truly critical for the electrochemical NRR process. The Cu–S bond was only broken in the NRR process and was not affected in the absence of N
2
in the aqueous solution. In the FeMo cofactor of nitrogenase, the Fe center provides the adsorption site for the associative adsorption of N
2
.
(54)
The Fe–S bond breaks in the N
2
adsorption process, and the atomic hydrogen delivered to the cofactor forms the sulfhydryl group in proximity to the Fe–N
2
site. Then, the sulfhydryl group is involved in the hydrogenation process, including the reductive elimination of H
2
molecules.
(54)
A similar associative adsorption mechanism has been suggested in the electrochemical N
2
reduction reactions.
(38,50)
N
2
H
x
intermediates on the electrocatalyst surface were found by in situ IR measurements, supporting the associative adsorption mechanism under ambient conditions. The NRR activity was also reported in metal sulfide catalysts.
(5,18,27)
However, the role of sulfur in the electrochemical NRR process was not determined to the best of our knowledge. Herein, NRR activity is observed on the Cu
9
S
5
/NC surface, but it disappears when the metal–sulfur bond is broken. Importantly, the catalytic activity is restored in sequential NH
3
production and catalyst regeneration cycles. These results imply that the metal–sulfur bond is critical to carry out electrochemical NH
3
production and is actively involved in the electrochemical N
2
reduction process.

In summary, a Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst was used as an NRR catalyst, resulting in significant NH
3
production activity and selectivity (10.8 ± 0.4 μg/hcm
2
or 630 ± 20 nmol/hcm
2
and 35 ± 3%, respectively). Importantly, the Cu
9
S
5
catalyst was degraded to Cu
2
O during the NRR process, resulting in a loss of catalytic activity. The Cu
9
S
5
surface was then reconstructed from the degraded electrode through an electrochemical sulfurization process. The importance of the metal–sulfide bond in NRR was demonstrated by the restored NH
3
production yield from the revived Cu
9
S
5
/NC surface. The degradation and regeneration process of the metal chalcogenide catalyst for electrochemical NH
3
production resembles the enzymatic N
2
fixation process discovered in the FeMo cofactor of nitrogenase. Further, the results strongly indicate that a robust catalyst providing a labile sulfhydryl functional group attached to a N
2
-adsorption metal center is required to achieve efficient electrochemical NH
3
production under ambient conditions.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In this work, we designed and prepared the Cu
9
S
5
/NC catalyst by a thermal heating reaction using a solid-state method, resulting in an FE of 35 ± 3% and a yield of 10.8 ± 0.4 μg/hcm
2
(or 630 ± 20 nmol/hcm
2
) at −0.5 V
RHE
for electrochemical NH
3
production in a 0.5 M Na
2
SO
4
electrolyte. However, the crystal structure of Cu
9
S
5
/NC was changed to Cu
2
O during the NRR reaction, resulting in no meaningful NH
3
production on the degraded catalyst surface. The regenerative redox cycle at metal sulfide electrodes was first demonstrated in this study. The Cu
9
S
5
surface was then reconstructed through an electrochemical sulfurization process in 50 mM and 100 mM Na
2
S electrolyte solutions. The NRR activity of Cu
9
S
5
/NC was restored in the reconstructed electrode, so to activate the NH
3
production in repeated NRR and regeneration processes. The importance of the metal–sulfide bond in NRR was demonstrated by the restored NH
3
production yield on the revived Cu
9
S
5
/NC surface. Similar to the enzymatic N
2
fixation process discovered in the FeMo cofactor of nitrogenase, the degradation and regeneration process of metal chalcogenide catalysts for electrochemical NH
3
production shows a similar mechanism to metal–sulfur chemistry. The results imply that to achieve efficient electrochemical NH
3
production under ambient conditions, a robust catalyst providing a labile sulfhydryl functional group attached to the N
2
-adsorption metal center is required. Hence, this study suggested a new electrochemical regeneration method for low-durability catalysts used in continuous NRR applications.

1
Binding of dinitrogen to an iron-sulfur-carbon site
Coric, Ilija; Mercado, Brandon Q.; Bill, Eckhard; Vinyard, David J.; Holland, Patrick L.
Nature (London, United Kingdom)
(
2015
),

(

CODEN:

; ISSN:
0028-0836
.
(
Nature Publishing Group

Nitrogenases are enzymes by which certain microorganisms convert atm. N2 to NH3, thereby providing essential N atoms for higher organisms. The most common nitrogenases reduce atm. N2 at the FeMo cofactor, a S-rich Fe-Mo cluster (FeMoco). The central Fe sites that are coordinated to S and C atoms in FeMoco have been proposed to be the substrate-binding sites, on the basis of kinetic and spectroscopic studies. In the resting state, the central Fe sites each have bonds to 3 S atoms and one C atom. The addn. of electrons to the resting state causes the FeMoco to react with N2, but the geometry and bonding environment of N2-bound species remain unknown. Here, the authors describe a synthetic complex with a S-rich coordination sphere that, upon redn., breaks an Fe-S bond and binds N2. The product is the 1st synthetic Fe-N2 complex in which Fe has bonds to S and C atoms, providing a model for N2 coordination in the FeMoco. The results demonstrate that breaking an Fe-S bond is a chem. reasonable route to N2 binding in the FeMoco, and show structural and spectroscopic details for weakened N2 on a S-rich Fe site.

The Haber-Bosch process to produce ammonia for fertilizer currently relies on carbon-intensive steam reforming of methane as a hydrogen source. We present an electrochem. pathway in which ammonia is produced by electrolysis of air and steam in a molten hydroxide suspension of nano-Fe2O3. At 200°C in an electrolyte with a molar ratio of 0.5 NaOH/0.5 KOH, ammonia is produced at 1.2 V (V) under 2 mA cm-2 of applied current at coulombic efficiency of 35% (35% of the applied current results in the six-electron conversion of N2 and water to ammonia, and excess H2 is cogenerated with the ammonia). At 250°C and 25 bar of steam pressure, the electrolysis voltage necessary for 2 mA cm-2 c.d. decreased to 1.0 V.

The photodecompn. of NH3 to H2 and N2 was carried out by using Pt-supported metal-doped TiO2 (Pt/M-TiO2, M: dopant element) photocatalyst in an aq. NH3 soln. under UV irradn. at room temp. Fe-doped TiO2 photocatalysts (Pt/Fe-TiO2) promoted the highest yield of H2 formation in the NH3 photodecompn. UV-visible diffuse reflectance spectra of Fe-doped TiO2 showed that the absorption edge of TiO2 was shifted from the UV to the visible light region by substitution with Fe. In addn., X-ray diffraction and ESR spectra showed that the dopant metals substituted a portion of the Ti4+ sites in the TiO2 crystal without changing TiO2 structure. Hence, it is indicated that TiO2 doped with Fe can utilize visible light wavelengths and effectively produce hydrogen from the decompn. of aq. NH3.

Constructing high-efficient and cost-saving catalysts for electrochem. N redn. reaction (NRR) under ambient conditions is of great significance, but quite challenging. Herein, foam-like composites comprised of small RhPx nanoparticles (NPs) and N, P co-doped C (NPC) framework are 1st reported as novel high-efficiency NRR electrocatalysts. The electronic structure and catalytic behavior of RhPx are modified by altering the contents of P in composites. D. function theory (DFT) calcns. prove that the introduction of P into the Rh lattice can dramatically reduce the catalytic reaction barrier and facilitate the intermediate process of catalytic reaction. Compared with most of the reported materials, this new catalyst possesses high NH3 (NH3) yield rate of 37.6μg h-1 mg-1cat. and Faraday efficiency (FE) of 7.64%, as well as good selectivity and superior stability in acid conditions. This work provides a theor. basis and practical scheme for the wide application of other robust transition metal phosphides electrocatalysts in NRR.

The influence of thermal treatment in hydrogen and nitrogen atm. of Co precursors in Co/MWCNTs system on the catalyst structure and catalytic activities in NH3 decompn. were studied. The cobalt-support interaction in cobalt supported on MWCNTs was controlled by varying the temp. of thermal treatment of Co precursor and reaction media. Due to the interaction of cobalt species with multi wall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), the Co/MWCNTs catalysts after pretreatment in nitrogen exhibited higher catalytic activity for NH3 decompn. comparing to that obsd. after hydrogen pretreatment of the sample. Cobalt dispersion in MWCNTs-supported catalysts was a function of thermal pretreatment temps. The studied samples were characterized by x-ray diffraction, HRTEM, thermo gravimetric anal., temp. programmed redn. and temp. programmed desorption.

Copper Single Atoms Anchored in Porous Nitrogen-Doped Carbon as Efficient pH-Universal Catalysts for the Nitrogen Reduction Reaction
Zang, Wenjie; Yang, Tong; Zou, Haiyuan; Xi, Shibo; Zhang, Hong; Liu, Ximeng; Kou, Zongkui; Du, Yonghua; Feng, Yuan Ping; Shen, Lei; Duan, Lele; Wang, John; Pennycook, Stephen J.

Artificial N fixation through the N redn. reaction (NRR) under ambient conditions is a potentially promising alternative to the traditional energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process. For this purpose, efficient catalysts are urgently required to activate and reduce N into NH3. Herein, by the combination of expts. and 1st-principles calcns., Cu single atoms, attached in a porous N-doped C network, provide highly efficient NRR electrocatalysis, which compares favorably with those previously reported. Benefiting from the high d. of exposed active sites and the high level of porosity, the Cu SAC exhibits high NH3 yield rate and faradaic efficiency (FE), specifically ∼53.3 ugNH3 h-1 mgcat.-1 and 13.8% under 0.1M KOH, ∼49.3 ugNH3 h-1 mgcat.-1 and 11.7% under 0.1M HCl, making them truly pH universal. They also show good stability with little current attenuation over 12 h of continuous operation. Cu-N2 coordination is identified as the efficient active sites for the NRR catalysis.

Two-Dimensional Mosaic Bismuth Nanosheets for Highly Selective Ambient Electrocatalytic Nitrogen Reduction
Li, Laiquan; Tang, Cheng; Xia, Bingquan; Jin, Huanyu; Zheng, Yao; Qiao, Shi-Zhang
ACS Catalysis
(

American Chemical Society

Electrochem. fixation of N2 to NH3 is a promising strategy to store renewable energy and mitigate greenhouse gas emissions. However, it usually suffers from extremely low NH3 yield and faradaic efficiency because of the lack of efficient electrocatalysts and the competing H evolution reaction. Herein, the authors report that the semiconducting Bi can be a promising catalyst for ambient electrocatalytic N2 redn. reaction (NRR). A two-dimensional mosaic Bi nanosheet (Bi NS) was fabricated via an in situ electrochem. redn. process and exhibited favorable av. NH3 yield and faradaic efficiency ≤2.54 ± 0.16 μgNH3 cm-2 h-1 (∼13.23 μg mgcat.-1 h-1) and 10.46 ± 1.45% at -0.8 V vs. reversible H electrode in 0.1M Na2SO4. The high NRR electrocatalytic activity of the Bi NS could be attributed to the sufficient exposure of edge sites coupled with effective p-orbital electron delocalization in the mosaic Bi nanosheets. The semiconducting feature, which limits surface electron accessibility, could effectively enhance the faradaic efficiency. This work highlights the potential importance of less reactive main group elements with tunable p-electron d., semiconducting property, and ingenious nanostructure for further exploration of N2 redn. reaction electrocatalysts.

Electrocatalytic N2 redn. to NH3 is an attractive method for artificial N2 fixation at ambient conditions. Herein, we demonstrate that Fe-NC materials could be efficient for electrochem. N2 redn. reaction (NRR) using iron phthalocyanine (FePc) with a well-defined FeN4 configuration as a model catalyst. By uniformly loading FePc mols. on porous carbon, it exhibits a high electrocatalytic activity for NRR with a NH3 yield rate of 137.95 μg h-1 mg-1FePc at a low potential of -0.3 V (vs RHE). Importantly, by making comparisons with phthalocyanine without the Fe center and performing control and poisoning expts. together with theor. calcns., we identify the Fe center in FeN4 as the most active site for NRR among five possible sites in FePc and discover that the preferred route is the alternating pathway of N2 on Fe. These results open up opportunities for further exploring metal-nitrogen-carbon materials for highly efficient electrochem. N2 fixation and NH3 prodn.

Electrochem. N fixation under ambient conditions proposes an attractive prospect to produce NH3, yet the process still suffers from the sluggish kinetics and is extremely sensitive to the structures of catalysts. Metal-free materials with tunable structure and electronic properties represent as alternative catalysts for electroredn. of N2. Here, the authors elaborately develop a corrosion engineering strategy that enables the heteroatom doping and etching of host graphdiyne (GDY) simultaneously, leading to the consequent Cl-doped ultrathin GDY (Cl-GDY) catalyst to realize effective N2 electroredn. The as-synthesized Cl-GDY can afford a relatively high NH3 yield rate of 10.7 μg h-1 cm-2 assocd. with a faradaic efficiency of 8.7% at -0.45 V and -0.4 V vs. the reversible H electrode, resp. The high performance of Cl-GDY dramatically broadens the scope of metal-free catalysts for artificial N fixation.

Electrochemical Synthesis of NH3 at Low Temperature and Atmospheric Pressure Using a γ-Fe2O3 Catalyst
Kong, Jimin; Lim, Ahyoun; Yoon, Changwon; Jang, Jong Hyun; Ham, Hyung Chul; Han, Jonghee; Nam, Sukwoo; Kim, Dokyoon; Sung, Yung-Eun; Choi, Jungkyu; Park, Hyun S.

The electrochem. synthesis of NH3 by the nitrogen redn. reaction (NRR) at low temp. (< 65°) and atm. pressure using nanosized γ-Fe2O3 electrocatalysts were demonstrated. The activity and selectivity of the catalyst was investigated both in a 0.1 M KOH electrolyte and when incorporated into an anion-exchange membrane electrode assembly (MEA). In a half-reaction expt. conducted in a KOH electrolyte, the γ-Fe2O3 electrode presented a faradaic efficiency of 1.9% and a wt.-normalized activity of 12.5 nmol h-1 mg-1 at 0.0 VRHE. However, the selectivity toward N2 redn. decreased at more neg. potentials owing to the competing proton redn. reaction. When the γ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles were coated onto porous carbon paper to form an electrode for a MEA, their wt.-normalized activity for N2 redn. was found to increase dramatically to 55.9 nmol h-1 mg-1. However, the wt.- and area-normalized N2 redn. activities of γ-Fe2O3 decreased progressively from 35.9-14.8 nmol h-1 mg-1 and from 0.105-0.043 nmol h-1 cm-2act, resp., during a 25 h MEA durability test. In summary, a study of the fundamental behavior and catalytic activity of γ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles in the electrochem. synthesis of NH3 under low temp. and pressure is presented.

The synthesis of NH3 is mainly dominated by the traditional energy-consuming Haber-Bosch process with a mass of CO2 emission. Electrochem. conversion of N2 to NH3 emerges as a carbon-free process for the sustainable artificial N2 redn. reaction (NRR), but requires an efficient and stable electrocatalyst. Here, we report that the Mo2C nanorod serves as an excellent NRR electrocatalyst for artificial N2 fixation to NH3 with strong durability and acceptable selectivity under ambient conditions. Such a catalyst shows a high Faradaic efficiency of 8.13% and NH3 yield of 95.1 μg h-1 mg-1cat at -0.3 V in 0.1 M HCl, surpassing the majority of reported electrochem. conversion NRR catalysts. D. functional theory calcn. was carried out to gain further insight into the catalytic mechanism involved.

The electrocatalytic conversion of nitrogen gas at ambient conditions represents a novel approach for ammonia synthesis to the sustainable society. It is crit. to understand the detailed pathways and mechanisms of this promising process to develop a highly efficient catalyst. Herein, the N, P co-doping carbon (NP-C-MOF-5) catalyst was prepd. for electrocatalytic N2 redn. in acid electrolytes under ambient temps. and pressures. Exptl. results showed that there are two products including NH3 and N2H4·H2O on the NP-C-MOF-5 cathode at -0.1 V vs. RHE with the yield of 1.08 and 5.77 × 10-4 μg h-1 mgcat.-1, resp. The efficient activation of dinitrogen for the prodn. of ammonia plays a crucial role in our modern society, considering the significant impact of ammonia on food, chems., and energy. As an attractive alternative to the century-old Haber-Bosch process which is responsible for 1-2% of global energy consumption, utilization of half the hydrogen produced globally, and ∼1% of global energy-related CO2 emissions, the ambient electrocatalytic nitrogen redn. reaction has attracted tremendous interest during the past few years. Some achievements have revealed the possibility of this process, but have also identified great challenges. The activity and selectivity of the nitrogen redn. reaction are fundamentally limited by competing hydrogen evolution and nitrogen scaling relations, while low prodn. rates and ubiquitous contaminants plague exptl. practices. Aiming toward higher accuracy and reproducibility of claimed results, and more meaningful, impactful, and insightful research, this tutorial review summarizes the present status and challenges in the study of ambient electrocatalytic nitrogen redn., followed by a thorough discussion of various exptl. parameters. We then recommend a series of protocols and best practices for expts., and also highlight some potential directions for future research in this exciting and important field.

The authors demonstrate a simple and effective chem. equil. regulation strategy to improve the efficiency of electrochem. NH3 synthesis by constructing electrochem. reaction system that works at significantly lower pressure than the Haber-Bosch process. Transferring the N redn. reaction from ambient conditions to a lightly pressurized environment not only accelerates the activation of the N N triple bond but also inhibits the competing reaction of H evolution while promoting the dissoln. and diffusion of N. The verification expt. of using well-designed Fe3Mo3C/C composite nanosheets as the N redn. catalyst shows that the lower pressure reaction system can improve the faradaic current efficiency by one order of magnitude. Also, the comparatively low-pressure reaction system can greatly reduce the cell voltage of the NH3 synthesis reaction (up to 33 %) even at the relatively low pressure of 0.7 MPa, which is of significance for decreasing the energy consumption of electrochem. NH3 synthesis under mild conditions.

With the large theor. capacity and environmental benignity, Cu sulfide (CuS) becomes a prospective candidate electrode material for supercapacitors. Electroconductive mesoporous carbonized clothes (Cc) was obtained by carbonizing the waste cotton fabrics. Then the CuS was galvanostatic electrodeposited on Cc to prep. the binder-free g-CuS/Cc electrode. In the galvanostatic electrodeposition process, CuS grew along the crystal surface to form regular nanosheets, and a part of Cu2+ were reduced to Cu1.1+. On account of the synergistic effect of electrochem. double layer capacitance with pseudocapacitance and the high sp. surface area (450.76 m2 g-1), the g-CuS/Cc composite displayed not only outstanding areal specific capacitance (4676 mF cm-2 at 2 mA cm-2) but also excellent cycling performance (89.8% retention after 10000 cycles). Meanwhile, the sym. flexible supercapacitor (SC) based on g-CuS/Cc electrodes with PVA-KOH gel electrolyte (g-CuS/Cc-SC) accomplished a high specific capacitance of 1333 mF cm-2 at 2 mA cm-2 as well as ultrahigh energy d. of 0.96 Wh cm-2 at the power d. of 4.36 W cm-2. Therefore, g-CuS/Cc shows a great potential for applications in the next generation of flexible energy storage devices.

The electrochem. N redn. reaction (NRR) was regarded as a promising alternative to the conventional Haber-Bosh process for NH3 synthesis. Inspired by the Fe-Mo-S cofactor in the enzyme nitrogenase, metal sulfide catalysts, mostly Fe- or Mo-based sulfides, have recently received great interest. Here, the authors propose Cu2-xS (0 ≤ x < 1) as an efficient NRR electrocatalyst. Electrochem. tests at room temp. and atm. pressure reveal that Cu1.81S achieves a high NH3 yield of 2.19μmol h-1 cm-2 along with a faradaic efficiency of 14.1% at -0.1 V vs. reversible H electrode in an aq. electrolyte. According to the authors' 1st-principles calcns., the superior NRR properties originate from the 3-fold-coordinate Cu sites in Cu1.81S. These sites enable N-H···S H bonding during N2Hy adsorption and stabilize the intermediates on the Cu2-xS surfaces, leading to a significant decrease in the overpotential limit for the NRR. Also, the 3-fold sites not only provide a bioinspired NRR pathway similar to that of nitrogenase but also enable both distal and alternating pathways, increasing the efficiency for the NRR. This study presents an attractive electrocatalyst for the NRR and opens an alternative route to explore chalcogenides and halides as NRR catalysts where the H-bonding mediation can similarly operate.

Redn. of N2 by nitrogenases occurs at an organometallic iron cofactor that commonly also contains either molybdenum or vanadium. The well-characterized resting state of the cofactor does not bind substrate, so its mode of action remains enigmatic. Carbon monoxide was recently found to replace a bridging sulfide, but the mechanistic relevance was unclear. Here we report the structural anal. of vanadium nitrogenase with a bound intermediate, interpreted as a μ2-bridging, protonated nitrogen that implies the site and mode of substrate binding to the cofactor. Binding results in a flip of amino acid glutamine 176, which hydrogen-bonds the ligand and creates a holding position for the displaced sulfide. The intermediate likely represents state E6 or E7 of the Thorneley-Lowe model and provides clues to the remainder of the catalytic cycle.

Electrochem. conversion reactions offer a new avenue to build high-capacity anodes for sodium-ion batteries. However, poor long-term cyclability and low coulombic efficiency at the first cycle remain a significant challenge for practical Na-ion battery applications. Herein, a novel hyperbranched polymer is used as a template and electrode additive to construct unique hierarchical Cu9S5 nanoplates. With an internal uniform distribution, the additive could regulate the morphol. and microstructure of Cu9S5 and offer a buffering matrix to alleviate nanoparticle aggregation and enhance solid-state Na+ ion diffusion. This Cu9S5 composite anode exhibits a high reversible capacity of 429 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1, a high coulombic efficiency of 94.3% at the first cycle, a superior rate capability of 300 mA h g-1 at 20 A g-1, and an outstanding cyclability with 82.2% capacity retention after 1000 cycles. The kinetic study reveals that Cu9S5-AHP nanoplates show a low charge transfer resistance and high Na+ diffusion coeff. (∼10-9 cm2 s-1). The present work suggests a potentially feasible anode material for sodium-ion batteries and, more significantly, demonstrates a novel strategy for the construction of high-performance conversion materials for sodium-ion batteries.

Over the present material synthesis routes, the sonochemical route is highly efficient and comfortable way to produce nanostructured materials. In this way, the copper sulfide (CuS-covellite) and sulfur doped reduced graphene oxide (S-rGO) nanocomposite was prepared by sonochemical method. Interestingly, the structure of the as-prepared S-rGO/CuS was changed from the covellite to digenite phase. Herein, the S-rGO was act as a mild oxidizer and liable for the structural transformations. These structural changes are sequentially studied by various physicochemical characterizations such as Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Transmission electron microscopy (TEM). After scrupulous structural evaluations, the transformation of CuS phase was identified and documented. This oxidized CuS has an excellent electrocatalytic activity when compare to the bulk CuS. This S-rGO/CuS was further used for the determination of glucose and acquired good electrocatalytic performances. This S-rGO/CuS was exhibited a wide linear concentration range, 0.0001-3.88 mM and 3.88-20.17 mM, and a low-level detection limit of 32 nM. Moreover, we have validated the practicability of our developed glucose sensor in real biological samples.

Highly N-doped crab shell-derived carbon nanofibers (CSCN) with enhanced CO2 and CH4 sorption capacity are discussed. Two carbonization temps. (600 and 900°) were used to control the CSCN N-doping level; the N-content of CSCN processed at 600° was higher than that processed at 900°. Following a judicious activation process to fine-tune ultra-microporosity (<1 nm) by hot CO2 treatment, CSCN from 600° carbonization with the highest ultra-microporosity had a higher CO2 uptake capacity vs. CSCN carbonized at 900° due to its higher N-doping level, although ultra-microporosity of both samples was similar. Similar CH4 sorption capacities were identified for both. Very efficient, selective CO2/N2 sepn. was achieved by CSCN carbonized at 600° with max. ultra-microporosity; similar selective CH4/N2 sepn. was obsd. for both of the most activated CSCN. As a result, relationships between the ultra-microporosity and CO2 and CH4 uptake capacity and N-doping effect were clearly elucidated.

Highly enhanced CO2 and H2 adsorption properties were achieved with a series of phenolic resin-based carbon spheres (resorcinol-formaldehyde carbon (RFC) and phenol-formaldehyde carbon (PFC)) by carbonization of RF and PF polymer (RFP and PFP) spheres synthesized via a sol-gel reaction and subsequent activation with hot CO2 or NH3 treatment. Monodisperse and size-tunable (100-600 nm) RFC and PFC spheres had intrinsic nitrogen contents (ca. 1.5 wt. %), which are attributed to the synthesis conditions that utilized NH3 as a basic catalyst as well as nitrogen precursor. A series of CO2-activated and N-doped RFC and PFC spheres showed almost perfect correlation (R2 = 0.99) between CO2 adsorption capacities and accumulated pore vols. of fine micropores (ultramicropore <1 nm) obtained using the nonlocal d. functional theory (NLDFT) model. Interestingly, NH3 activation served not only as an effective method for heteroatom doping (i.e., nitrogen) into the carbon framework but also as an excellent activation process to fine-tune the surface area and pore size distribution (PSD). Increased nitrogen doping levels up to ca. 2.8 wt. % for NH3-activated RFC spheres showed superior CO2 adsorption capacities of 4.54 (1 bar) and 7.14 mmol g-1 (1 bar) at 298 and 273 K, resp. Compared to CO2-activated RFC spheres with similar ultramicropore vol. presenting CO2 uptakes of 4.41 (1 bar) and 6.86 mmol g-1 (1 bar) at 298 and 273 K, resp., NH3-activated nitrogen-enriched RFC was found to have elevated chemisorption ability. Moreover, prolonged activation of RFC and PFC spheres provided ultrahigh surface areas, one of which reached 4079 m2g-1 with an unprecedented superb H2 uptake capacity of 3.26 wt. % at 77 K (1 bar), representing one of the best H2 storage media among carbonaceous materials and metal-org. frameworks (MOFs).

The promoting effect of B, F, P, and S to N-doped carbons for NRR is different from the exptl. evolution and anal. In there, N,B-codoping of porous C has the greatest promotional effect in NRR. From in situ FTIR spectroscopic findings, this N,B dual-doped carbons follow the associative mechanism during NRR process.

also exhibits high selectivity (no formation of hydrazine) and electrochem. stability. The moderate electron structure induced by the interaction between O-MoC and N-doped carbon shells can effectively weaken the activity of hydrogen evolution reaction and increase the faradaic efficiency of NRR. Addnl., by applying the in situ Fourier transform IR spectroscopy, an associative reaction pathway is proposed on
[email protected]
This work provides new insights into the rational design of carbon-encapsulated metal nanoparticles as efficient catalysts for NRR at ambient conditions.

For high performance of elec. double layer capacitors (EDLCs), a high sp. surface area (SSA) and N-doping level, and small particle size of carbonaceous materials, were believed to be crucial factors. However, there were few reports on simultaneous study of the structure-properties relations of carbons and the electrochem. performances of EDLCs. Herein, the authors report the relation between the structural properties of carbons, such as the SSA, N-doping, and particle size, and the electrochem. properties of EDLCs by using well-defined carbons. Monodisperse and size-tunable resorcinol-formaldehyde C (RFC) spheres were synthesized and activated by hot CO2 treatment to increase the SSA up to 3958 m2/g (RFC_C390 sample). When the specific capacitances of the RFC spheres were plotted in terms of their SSAs, an almost perfect correlation (R2 = 0.99) was obsd., which confirmed the linear relation between the specific capacitance and the SSA. N-doped melanin C (MC) spheres were synthesized and subsequently activated for N-doping effect. Activated MC (MC_C130), which exhibited similar SSA (2618 m2/g) and size (301 nm) but a different N-doping level (3.1%) compared with those (2793 m2/g, 312 nm, and 1.3%, resp.) of the activated RFC spheres (RFC_C120), displayed higher specific capacitance (288 F/g), capacitance retention (64%), and long term stability over 5000 cycles (93%) compared with those (260 F/g, 58%, and 90%, resp.) of the RFC counterparts. To observe the particle size effect, different sizes (98, 280, and 579 nm) of RFC spheres with similar SSAs (3981, 3958, and 3898 m2/g, resp.) and pore size distributions were prepd., such that the smallest RFC revealed the best EDLC performance in terms of specific capacitance (360 F/g), capacitance retention (70%), and long term stability over 5000 cycles (98%), all of which could be compared with the values reported in the literature. Also, all of the C samples were analyzed by using electrochem. impedance spectroscopy for confirming the structure-properties relations of C spheres with the electrochem. performances of EDLCs.

Rechargeable magnesium batteries (rMBs) have been recognized as one of most promising next-generation energy storage devices with high energy and power d. However, the development of rMBs has been hampered by the lack of usable cathode materials with high capacity and cycling stability. Herein, we report an ultra-rapid, cost-effective, and scalable synthesis of ultrathin CuS hierarchical nanosheets by a one-step microwave-assisted prepn. Benefiting from the exceptional structural configuration, when used as the cathode material for rMBs at room temp., the CuS hierarchical nanosheets deliver a high reversible discharge capacity of 300 mA h g-1 at 20 mA g-1, remarkable rate capability (256.5 mA h g-1 at 50 mA g-1 and 237.5 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1), and excellent cycling stability (135 mA h g-1 at 200 mA g-1 over 200 cycles). To date, the obtained excellent electrochem. performances are superior to most results ever reported for cathode materials of rMBs.

Cu2-xS compds. with low-cost and low-toxicity elements have been reported as good candidates for thermoelec. (TE) application. In this work, the Cu1.96S powders were synthesized by both hydrothermal synthesis (HS) and mech. alloying (MA) methods. The HS synthesis process and mechanism was discussed in detail. The polycryst. Cu1.96S bulk materials were obtained by condensing the powders (prepd. by HS and MA) or the mixed HS and MA powers with the different ratio (1:0, 9:1, 1:9 and 0:1) using spark plasma sintering (SPS) technique. The phase structure, microstructure of the powders and bulk samples were checked. The results show that the Cu1.96S powders synthesized by HS are more stable than the powder prepd. by MA method during the SPS process. And the thermoelec. properties of all bulk samples were investigated in detail at the temp. ranges from 323 to 773 K. The Cu1.96S bulk sample sintered by using mixed powders of 90 wt% HSed powders and 10 wt% MAed powders obtained the max. ZT value of 1.01 at 773 K, which is currently the highest reported value for the Cu1.96S system at this temp.

Recent progress in electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction
Guo, Xiaoxi; Du, Huitong; Qu, Fengli; Li, Jinghong

A review. Ammonia (NH3) is an activated nitrogen building block for the manuf. of modern fertilizers, plastics, fibers, explosives, etc.; however, its prodn. is limited to the traditional Haber-Bosch process. Very recently, electrocatalytic redn. of nitrogen (N2) has been demonstrated to be a clean and sustainable approach to produce NH3, which has aroused widespread attention. All types of electrocatalysts have been developed and designed for the electrochem. nitrogen redn. reaction (NRR). To achieve both high catalytic performance and selectivity, electrocatalysts must be rationally designed to optimize the mass transport, chemi(physi)sorption, and transfer of protons and electrons. In this review, we summarize the recent developments on electrocatalysts for N2 fixation. First, we discuss the reaction mechanisms of the NRR. Second, three categories of electrocatalysts according to their chem. compns. are surveyed. Then, the effects of different types of electrolytes on NRR activity and electrolyte choice are also summarized. Finally, the existing challenges and future perspectives are discussed.

Scanning electrochem. microscopy was used to probe the influence of a driving force on the heterogeneous electron transfer (ET) processes at the externally polarized H2O/1,2-dichloroethane interface. Being a part of the driving force, the Galvani p.d. at the interface, Δowφ, can be quant. controlled in a wide range, allowing the precise measurements of the rate consts. of the ET reactions. Two opposite systems were chosen. One was Zn 5,10,15,20-tetraphenyl-21H,23H-porphyrin (ZnPor, O)/Fe(CN)64- (W), and the other was TCNQ (O)/Fe(CN)63- (W). For both systems studied, the relations between the rate const. and the Δowφ were of parabolic shape; i.e., the rate consts. increased initially with the Δowφ until reaching a max. and then decreased steadily as the Δowφ increased further. This is in accordance with the prediction of the Marcus theory. This is the 1st report that the Marcus inverted region can be obsd. electrochem. at an unmodified liq./liq. interface with only one redox couple at each phase. The effect of the concns. of the org. supporting electrolyte is also discussed.

The passivity degrdn. of UNS N08800 in solns. contg. Cl- and S2O32- was studied by using polarization curve, electrochem. impedance spectroscopy (EIS), and XPS. The passivity breakdown heavily depends on anodic potentials, concn. ratios of Cl- to S2O32-, and the compn. of materials. A combined effect between Cl- and S2O32- on pitting corrosion is obsd. at high anodic potentials at which the passive film is broken down; in this situation, S2O32- ions can enter into the pits by electromigration, and they are reduced to Sads and S2-, stabilizing the metastable pits and accelerate the pit growth rate. However, there is no such combined effect at low anodic potentials when the passive film is intact, on the contrary, S2O32- is beneficial to passivity in chloride solns. At low anodic potentials, the interaction of S2O32- with an intact passive layer is weak, and the adsorption of S2O32- would mitigate the detrimental effect of Cl- ions.

Ammonia as the source of most fertilizers has become one of the most important chems. globally. It also is being increasingly considered as an easily transported carrier of hydrogen energy that can be generated from "stranded" renewable-energy resources. However, the traditional Haber-Bosch process for the prodn. of ammonia from atm. nitrogen and fossil fuels is a high temp. and pressure process that is energy intensive, currently producing more than 1.6% of global CO2 emissions. An ambient temp., electrochem. synthesis of ammonia is an attractive alternative approach, but has, to date, not been achieved at high efficiency. We report in this work the use of ionic liqs. that have high N2 soly. as electrolytes to achieve high conversion efficiency of 60% for N2 electro-redn. to ammonia on a nanostructured iron catalyst under ambient conditions.

Developing efficient noble-metal-free catalysts for the electrochem. N2 redn. reaction (NRR) under ambient conditions shows promise in fertilizer prodn. and H storage. Here, as a proof-of-concept prototype, the authors design and implement an Fe-N/C-C nanotube (CNT) catalyst derived from a metal-org. framework and C-nanotube-based composite with built-in Fe-N3 active sites. This catalyst exhibits enhanced NRR activity with NH3 prodn. (34.83 μg h-1 mg-1cat.), faradaic efficiency (9.28% at -0.2 V vs. RHE), selectivity, and stability in 0.1M KOH aq. media under mild conditions. Exptl. and theor. results both reveal that Fe-N3 species are the primary catalytically active centers for the NRR. This work provides insight into precise construction of more efficient and stable NRR electrocatalysts and further expands the possibilities of transition metal-N-C (M-N-C)-based nanomaterials in NRR fields.

Nitrogen binding to the FeMo-cofactor of nitrogenase
Schimpl, Johannes; Petrilli, Helena M.; Bloechl, Peter E.
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(

Here, d. functional calcns. are presented to unravel the 1st steps of N2 fixation by nitrogenase. The individual steps leading from the resting state to N2 binding at the FeMo-cofactor with a central N ligand were characterized. The calcns. indicated that the Fe-Mo cage opens as N2 binds to the cluster. In the resting state, the central cage was overall neutral. Electrons and protons were transferred in an alternating manner. Upon N2 binding, one protonated S bridge was broken. An axial and a bridged binding mode of N2 were identified. Adsorption at the Mo site was investigated but appeared to be less favorable than binding at Fe sites. Thus, the calcns. indicate that N2 binds to an Fe site of the central cage and not to the Mo site.

Nakayama, Shigeyoshi; Notoya, Takenori; Osakai, Toshiyuki

A review. Until recently, there were two conflicting views about the order of copper oxides (Cu2O and CuO) in their cathodic redn. with a neutral or weak alk. electrolyte (typically 0.1 M KCl). In 2001, a strongly alk. electrolyte (SAE; i.e., 6 M KOH + 1 M LiOH) was employed to achieve a perfect sepn. of the redn. peaks of the two oxides. The oxides were reduced in SAE according to a thermodn. order, i.e., "CuO → Cu2O", and also that the redn. of CuO occurred in one step. At an extremely slow scan rate of <0.2 mV s-1, however, CuO appears to be reduced in two steps via Cu2O. The developed method with SAE can be applied to anal. of various corrosion products, including Cu2S, Cu(OH)2, and patinas. Use of the developed method has allowed researchers to clarify the mechanism of the atm. corrosion of copper.

Nitrogenases are enzymes by which certain microorganisms convert atm. N2 to NH3, thereby providing essential N atoms for higher organisms. The most common nitrogenases reduce atm. N2 at the FeMo cofactor, a S-rich Fe-Mo cluster (FeMoco). The central Fe sites that are coordinated to S and C atoms in FeMoco have been proposed to be the substrate-binding sites, on the basis of kinetic and spectroscopic studies. In the resting state, the central Fe sites each have bonds to 3 S atoms and one C atom. The addn. of electrons to the resting state causes the FeMoco to react with N2, but the geometry and bonding environment of N2-bound species remain unknown. Here, the authors describe a synthetic complex with a S-rich coordination sphere that, upon redn., breaks an Fe-S bond and binds N2. The product is the 1st synthetic Fe-N2 complex in which Fe has bonds to S and C atoms, providing a model for N2 coordination in the FeMoco. The results demonstrate that breaking an Fe-S bond is a chem. reasonable route to N2 binding in the FeMoco, and show structural and spectroscopic details for weakened N2 on a S-rich Fe site.

The Haber-Bosch process to produce ammonia for fertilizer currently relies on carbon-intensive steam reforming of methane as a hydrogen source. We present an electrochem. pathway in which ammonia is produced by electrolysis of air and steam in a molten hydroxide suspension of nano-Fe2O3. At 200°C in an electrolyte with a molar ratio of 0.5 NaOH/0.5 KOH, ammonia is produced at 1.2 V (V) under 2 mA cm-2 of applied current at coulombic efficiency of 35% (35% of the applied current results in the six-electron conversion of N2 and water to ammonia, and excess H2 is cogenerated with the ammonia). At 250°C and 25 bar of steam pressure, the electrolysis voltage necessary for 2 mA cm-2 c.d. decreased to 1.0 V.
